image.altText: The inside of the stadium showing crowds, people on the field and fireworks.

props.synopsis: The 2032 Brisbane Olympics have caused a stir at home over stadium plans but for the International Olympic Committee a higher-stakes game is being played.

title.children: The battle for the future of the Olympic Games is being played out in Brisbane and it's about more than stadiums

image.altText: A close-up of OJ Simpson wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: OJ Simpson, the former American football star at the centre of a double-murder trial that gripped the world in the 1990s, dies of cancer.

title.children: OJ Simpson, American footballer accused of ex-wife's murder, dies aged 76

image.altText: A rocket on scaffolding is lifted up on a launch pad.

props.synopsis: It's taken the Gilmore brothers nearly 10 years to build and design a locally made orbital rocket. Space enthusiasts are set to flock to north Queensland to see it lift off.

title.children: Pointed towards the sky, this Australian-first rocket is set to blast a small town into the global spotlight

image.altText: The long, slanted nose of a blue, grey and black bullet train sits on a special concrete track wit one metal rail.

props.synopsis: China has the world's fastest train but it wants to push speeds even higher. It has recently run a train through a low-vacuum tube at speeds of more than 600 kph — but the designers want it to ultimately reach a blistering 4,000 kph.

title.children: 'Commuting 400 kms in around half an hour': China's latest mag-lev development could change how cities work

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks out to the audience, he wears a yellow tie with a suit

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's set-piece policy announcement on Thursday was not short on ambition, but for now was mostly a re-announcement. What are the prospects of his future made in Australia?

title.children: The PM is heralding the dawn of a new manufacturing era, but it may not be so simple

image.altText: A graphic with a man in the foreground and wind farms in the background

props.synopsis: Australians will be paying more for energy in the future and they're not yet prepared for that reality, says Alinta CEO Jeff Dimery.

title.children: We were promised cleaner energy would equal cheaper energy. This energy boss says that’s a half-truth

image.altText: A composite image showing Peter Dutton in a high-vis vest and Anthony Albanese in a rugby jersey.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton was trying to turn the blowtorch on Labor for its handling of the Israel-Gaza war, but his controversial comments left him facing questions instead.

title.children: Dutton sought to turn the blowtorch on Albanese and Wong. He ended up facing his own questions

image.altText: A free flowing artesian bore pushes hot water from the Great Artesian Basin to a small pond

props.synopsis: Peak farming bodies say a mining giant's proposal to store waste carbon dioxide in Australia's biggest underground freshwater system puts the nation's food production system at risk.

title.children: Farmers, politicians unite to fight carbon capture 'science experiment' in Great Artesian Basin

image.altText: A person in a white protective suit stands next to a lake holding a dead crane.

props.synopsis: Australia is one of the last places on the planet free from high pathogenicity bird flu. But authorities warn there's an increased risk of an outbreak here as scientists say the world is in an animal pandemic.

title.children: Bird flu has spread to dairy cows in the US. Here's why the world is watching

image.altText: A monopoly board with every property being a "go to jail"

props.synopsis: Police Commissioner Michael Murphy says he expects more racist material to surface from within the NT Police Force, after reports an image of a "Black Monopoly" board was emailed around the force in 2008.

title.children: NT police commissioner says 'Black Monopoly' email circulated among officers is 'very concerning'

image.altText: A drone shot of a mostly sunken ship wreck near a beach.

props.synopsis: An untold amount of black, toxic oil is contained within the corroding wrecks of World War II ships scattered around the Pacific. And it's leaking into the ocean.

title.children: These rusting shipwrecks are a big drawcard for divers. They're also ticking time bombs

image.altText: A large crowd gathered outside the Opera House

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton repeats that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese missed a chance to respond strongly to protests outside the Opera House against Israel in October last year, as he again compares the moment to the Port Arthur massacre.

title.children: Peter Dutton doubles down on comparing pro-Palestine protest and Port Arthur massacre responses

image.altText: A three-panel collage of Bruce Springsteen, Kiss' Gene Simmons, and Katy Perry

props.synopsis: Superstar artists are selling their rights at blockbuster prices. But who's buying? What's driving this trend? And who benefits?

title.children: From Kiss to Katy Perry, many artists are letting go of their rights. Here's why

image.altText: A magpie and a dog sit on a deck overlooking a yard.

props.synopsis: Molly the magpie, whose viral fame led to his rescuers signing a book deal, will be reunited with his best friend, Peggy the staffy — but conditions apply.

title.children: Molly the magpie is homeward bound, but carers barred from using bird for commercial gain

image.altText: Julian Assange seen through the window of a police van.

props.synopsis: An off-the-cuff remark by Joe Biden has taken the world by surprise and evoked hopes among the supporters of Julian Assange that the US President may be considering Australia's request to drop his prosecution. Here are five quick questions on the comments and how we got here.

title.children: What could Joe Biden's comments about Julian Assange mean?

image.altText: A Vietnamese woman wearing a white shirt sitting in court flanked by security women.

props.synopsis: Truong My Lan's company was building luxury residential complexes and shopping centres. She's now been sentenced to death.

title.children: Vietnamese property tycoon sentenced to death after embezzling $US12.5 billion

image.altText: The Prime Minister stands in a leafy green area holding a press conference

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's government is defining itself by robust stances, and two totally different topics this week are showing us how.

title.children: After this week, Albanese government can't be accused of being too cautious

image.altText: a man sitting with his arm around a woman

props.synopsis: More than two years on from the 2022 floods, this family occupies an unlockable "half a house" that's constantly damp and prone to vermin.

title.children: Queensland family lived in 'uninhabitable' home with backyard steeped in sewerage after 2022 floods

image.altText: Search crew standing in between two police vehicles.

props.synopsis: Police are expected to continue their search for the body of missing woman Samantha Murphy on Friday, after spending Thursday scouring a new area of bushland near Ballarat.

title.children: Fresh search for Samantha Murphy to resume Friday after wrapping for day

image.altText: Smoke and fire coming from a building in the distance with more buildings in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Ukraine is warning it is running low on air defence systems, as it calls for more assistance in its two-year war against Russia.

title.children: Kyiv power plant destroyed in Russian missile strike

image.altText: A Qatar Airways Airbus A350-900 on the tarmac on a lightly cloudy day.

props.synopsis: The justice finds the incident did not happen on board the plane or by the airline's employees and as such, an international aviation convention does not apply.

title.children: Federal Court throws out case against Qatar Airways over invasive and degrading strip searches

image.altText: A stylised image of a mother cradling a baby.

props.synopsis: Damning claims by an SA government whistleblower have been levelled against the way child protection authorities are removing newborns from their mothers at public hospitals, sometimes just minutes after giving birth.

title.children: A whistleblower says mothers who 'haven't actually completed the birthing process' are having babies removed

image.altText: Lindsey Graham speaks at a podium while Donald Trump watches from behind.

props.synopsis: The former president hoped his abortion video would take the issue "out of play" before November's US election, but even some of his allies are determined not to let that happen.

title.children: Trump's anger at a Republican ally exposes his election ploy – and how it threatens to backfire

image.altText: A for lease sign at a picket fence

props.synopsis: Australian renters facing all-time high asking rents and record low vacancy rates across the country, but there could be relief in sight.

title.children: 'Never-ending run of rent rises' expected to hit a 'tipping point' later this year as population growth slows

image.altText: A man with a shaved head, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says personal income tax has increased by a "record" 23 per cent since Labor came to power. RMIT ABC Fact Check runs the numbers.

title.children: Fact check: Have personal income taxes risen by a 'record' 23 per cent under Anthony Albanese?

image.altText: Australian men's basketball team members celebrate with their Olympic bronze medals, as most of them wear masks.

props.synopsis: Australia's men's basketball team for the Paris Olympics is announced, with a 22-man squad still to be trimmed by 10 prior to the action starting in July.

title.children: 'Aussie ball' mindset behind versatile Boomers squad for Paris Olympics

image.altText: A player mimics crying as a sledge to another AFL player during a match

props.synopsis: Former Brisbane Lions captain Dayne Zorko says teammate Noah Answerth's mock crying, referencing an ugly incident from 2022, was "not the way we want to win".

title.children: Lion's gesture mocks Petty over crying incident following 2022 sledge

image.altText: A screenshot of someone being prompted to use the Palestinian flag emoji when they type the word Jerusalem into their iPhone.

props.synopsis: When iPhone users who have downloaded the latest software update type in the word "Jerusalem", they will see a prompt for the Palestinian flag emoji. Here's why that may have happened.

title.children: How an iPhone text 'bug' sparked global speculation that Apple staff were staging a small protest over Palestine

image.altText: A worker wearing a face mask works on a production line manufacturing bicycle steel rims in China.

props.synopsis: The prime minister sees an agenda to grow local green manufacturing as not only economically and strategically vital, but a political no-brainer. But that's only if it all works.

title.children: Albanese says a change as big as the industrial revolution is coming — you could call it the 'government intervention revolution'

image.altText: President Biden wears sunglasses in a suit speaks behind a lectern to a journalist.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden indicates the United States could abandon its prosecution of the Australian WikiLeaks founder ahead of revealing plans to develop an integrated missile defence system with Australia and Japan.

title.children: Biden 'considering' dropping pursuit of Assange as US, Australia plan missile system with Japan

image.altText: A man is smiling at the camera holding an oversized jackfruit.

props.synopsis: Jackfruit usually weigh between 5 and 15 kilograms, but a grower south of Cairns has just harvested this "impressive" 45-kilogram monster fruit.

title.children: 'Geez, that's a bit heavy!' Jumbo jackfruit stuns farmer in Far North Queensland

image.altText: South Korean male politician stands in the centre of a room surrounded by reporters.

props.synopsis: South Korea's liberal opposition parties score a landslide victory in a parliamentary election held on Wednesday, dealing a resounding blow to President Yoon Suk Yeol and his conservative party.

title.children: South Korean ruling party suffers bruising defeat in parliamentary election
